questions.text: The below deformity is seen in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Deformities in RA-

  • Ulnar deviation of fingers at the level of metacarpophalangeal joints

Boutonniere deformity-

  • Boutonniere deformity occurs when the proximal interphalangeal joint of a finger is flexed and the distal joint is extended.

Swan neck deformity:

  • Swan Neck Deformities are seen with rheumatoid arthritis, characterized by hyperextension of the PIP joint and flexion of the DIP joint due to an imbalance of muscle forces on the PIP

Rheumatoid nodules:

  • Rheumatoid nodules are firm lumps that appear under the skin in up to 20% of patients with RA. They usually occur in overexposed joints that are subject to trauma, such as the finger joints and elbows.
  • They are the pathognomic features of the RA.

Z - Deformity of the thumb:

  • Z - deformity is a musculoskeletal manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis presenting in the thumb, with the combination of flexion of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint, hyperextension of the interphalangeal (IP) joint

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with a 2-month history of pain, swelling, and stiffness in both wrists and the small joints of her hands. She notes that her morning stiffness lasts over an hour, but it gradually improves as she moves around during the day. She also reports fatigue and a mild low-grade fever. On exam, you find symmetric synovitis affecting the MCPs and PIPs, with a slight warmth to the touch. Which of the following is the most specific antibody in the above condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above description corresponds to RA, and the most common antibody is the anti-CCP antibody.

Rheumatoid Arthritis:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune inflammatory arthritis. The body's immune system mistakenly attacks the synovial lining of joints causing inflammation-leading to pain, swelling, and stiffness.
  • It typically affects small joints of the hands and wrists, often symmetrically, and can involve larger joints as the disease progresses.

Clinical features:

  • Morning stiffness lasting >1 hour is a hallmark of RA-it typically improves with gentle activity or warmth.
  • This phenomenon, also known as the "gelling phenomenon", reflects inflammatory activity peaking after periods of inactivity.
  • It correlates with circadian peaks in pro-inflammatory cytokines (like IL-6) and relatively low night-time cortisol.

Investigations in rheumatoid arthritis-

  • Routine blood investigations: Hb may be low; white cell counts are raised along with a raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) levels.
  • Rheumatoid factor (RF): The RF is an IgM autoantibody against the Fc region of IgG, seen in almost two-thirds of patients with RA. Its detection can suggest the diagnosis. However, early in the disease, the levels are lower; therefore, the sensitivity is lower, and hence, it is not useful for screening purposes.
  • Neither is the presence of RF specific for RA, as it can be seen in 5% of healthy populations and diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), tuberculosis (TB), Sjogren's syndrome, syphilis, chronic liver disease, sarcoidosis, leprosy, infectious mononucleosis and malaria.
  • Anti-cyclic citrullinated polypeptide (anti-CCP): Anti-CCP antibodies are positive in up to 98% of cases. These are more specific than the RA factor and may be positive very early in the course of the disease. Positivity indicates a bad prognosis.
  • Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) may also be raised in RA.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a history of fatigue, weight loss and polyarthralgia for the last 5 years. Her hand and wrist radiograph are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • X-ray shows Severe osteopenia and swan neck deformities in several fingers. Both these findings, along with clinical history, point towards RA.
  • Radiological findings in RA:
    • Soft tissue shadow at the level of the joint because of joint effusion or synovial hypertrophy(Earliest finding).
    • Reduced joint space
    • Erosion of articular margins
    • Subchondral cysts
    • Juxta-articular osteopenia
    • Deformities of the hand and fingers
  • Osteoarthritis(Option B)- Heberden nodes and Bouchard nodes are seen.
  • Psoriatic arthritis(Option C)- Pencil in cup deformity
  • Neuropathic Joints(Option D)-Characterised by joint destruction and bone fragmentation, but usually in weight-bearing joints and with severe degenerative change.

Key takeaways:

questions.text: Rheumatoid arthritis is a relatively common autoimmune disease, with multiple treatment options. Which of the following is an example of a drug class that has been shown to halt or reverse the progression of this disease in most patients?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • MTX is currently considered a drug of first choice in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It is a non-biologic Disease Modifying Anti-Rheumatic Drug (DMARD).
  • Infliximab (Option A) is a biological TNF-α inhibitor that, when combined with methotrexate, further slows progression, but methotrexate remains the essential backbone therapy.
  • Azathioprine(Option B)- It is used only in conditions where other DMARDs fail to give results as it is associated with significant complications.
  • Prednisone(Option D)- Corticosteroids are used as adjuncts to therapy to reduce inflammation. They do not halt or reverse the progression of the disease.

Different drugs used in the treatment of RA:

questions.text: What mechanism of action of low-dose methotrexate in the treatment of RA?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Through inhibition of an intracellular enzyme, MTX in low doses, causes the accumulation of adenosine. Adenosine has potent anti-inflammatory effects, including a reduction in the number of activated T cells and reduced levels of TNF-alpha.
  • Inhibition of dihydrofolate is a mechanism that is responsible for the anti-cancer effects of MTX produced at higher doses.

questions.text: Which of the following medications, when combined with methotrexate, is more effective than methotrexate alone in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tetracycline was initially used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) because Mycoplasma was thought to be the causative agent.
  • It was later found that tetracyclines have biological effects on the inflammatory and immunologic cascade by inhibiting collagenase activity.
  • Collagenase is an enzyme involved in breaking down macromolecules in the connective tissue, contributing to the pathologic changes of RA.
  • In a prospective study, O'Dell et al found that initial therapy with methotrexate plus doxycycline was superior to treatment with methotrexate alone.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with a 2-year history of insidious onset of low back pain and stiffness, most notable in the mornings and after prolonged sitting. He wakes up at night with back pain that eases once he gets out of bed. He reports improvement with exercise and worsening with rest. He also describes occasional alternating buttock pain and heel pain, but no history of trauma. He's experienced persistent fatigue and has had two episodes of sudden left eye pain and sensitivity to light in the past year. Physical exam reveals reduced lumbar flexion (Schober's test +), decreased chest expansion, and tenderness over the sacroiliac joints. X-ray of the sacroiliac joints demonstrates sclerosis and joint space narrowing. The above condition is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above clinical scenario with morning stiffness improving with movement, axial spine and sacroiliac joint pain in a young man, presence of enthesitis (heel pain), uveitis, reduced spinal mobility, and sacroiliac joint X-ray changes-is diagnostic of ankylosing spondylitis.

Ankylosing Spondylitis:

  • Chronic inflammatory disease of the spine and sacroiliac joints, often progressing to stiffness and spinal fusion ("bamboo spine").
  • Typically affects young adults (onset <45 years), with a male predominance but also occurs in women.
  • Strongly associated with HLA-B27, though not everyone with the gene develops AS. HLA B27 is positive in 90% of cases
  • HLA B 27 positivity is seen in a group of diseases called seronegative spondyloarthropathies, which include Ankylosing spondylosis, Psoriatic Arthropathy, Enteropathic arthritis and Reactive arthritis.

Clinical features:

Inflammatory Back Pain:

  • Insidious onset, lasting ≥3 months, worse in the morning or after rest, and improves with exercise.
  • Often includes night pain and morning stiffness ≥30 mins

Enthesitis & Peripheral Involvement:

  • Inflammation at tendon/ligament insertions, e.g. Achilles tendonitis or heel pain.
  • May involve peripheral joints (hips, shoulders) and cause dactylitis ("sausage digits").

Extra-articular Features:

  • Anterior uveitis in ~20-35% of patients .
  • Possible pulmonary (chest wall restriction), cardiac (aortitis, conduction issues), IBD, and osteoporosis/fracture risk.

X-Ray shows:

  • Haziness around SI joint (earliest change)
  • Syndesmophytes (bridging osteophytes)
  • Bamboo spine.
  • Dagger sign
  • Shiny corner sign (Romanus sign)

Treatment:

  • NSAIDS and TNF Inhibitors.
  • Indomethacin is the most commonly used NSAIDS

questions.text: Gaenslen's test is used to identify which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gaenslen's test is used for the diagnosis of sacroiliitis. The only cause of sacroiliitis among the options is Ankylosing spondylosis.

The signs and tests for sacroiliitis include:

  • Tenderness localized to posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) (as PSIS overlies SI joints)
  • SI side-to-side compression test: The patient is in the side-lying position, and the examiner's hands are placed over the upper part of the iliac crest, pressing toward the floor. The movement causes strain in the SI joint. A positive test is indicated by pain in the SI joint.
  • Gaenslen's test: The patient lies on his or her back, and the examiner maximally flexes the hip on the normal side (by pushing the knee towards the patient's chest) and extends the affected hip (by allowing it to fall over the side of the table). The test is considered positive if the patient complains of pain over the SI joint.
  • Pump handle test: The patient lies supine; the examiner grasps the affected side knee of the patient with one hand, flexes the knee and hip, and forces it toward the opposite shoulder across the chest. Pain over the involved SI joints indicates a positive test.
  • Patric test/FABER test: The test is performed by keeping the limb flexed, abducted and externally rotated (FABER). If pain is elicited on the ipsilateral side anteriorly, it is suggestive of hip joint pathology on the same side. If pain is elicited on the contralateral side posteriorly around the SI joint, it is suggestive of pain arising from the SI joint.

X-Ray showing Sacroiliitis:

questions.text: Chronic fluorosis is caused by drinking water with fluoride content of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chronic Fluorosis:

  • Chronic fluorosis is seen in localities where the water supply contains > 10 ppm fluoride (Davidson).
  • Fluorosis is characterized by excessive deposition of calcium in bone & soft tissues due to increased intake of fluorides through drinking water.
  • Clinical features:
    • Dental fluorosis- earliest sign of fluorosis (mottling of the enamel) – MC involve the incisors of the upper jaw.
    • Skeletal fluorosis- pain in back & joints, stiff spine, paranesthesia, spastic paraparesis & anaemia.
  • Radiological findings:
    • Spine: Calcification of posterior longitudinal ligament.
    • Pelvis: Calcification of ischial pubic & sacroiliac ligaments
    • Forearm & leg: calcification of interosseous membrane.
  • Treatment:
    • Defluoridation of water (Nalgonda technique)

questions.text: A child from a small village in Bihar has long bone pain, is weak and lethargic and on examination, he has bow legs. The X-ray reports show an increase in bone density, osteophytes and dismorphic joint space. Possible diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hint in the question is a child from a village of Bihar with Genu varum/bow legged, long bone pain and X-Rays showing increased bone density, which characteristically focuses towards Fluorosis.
  • Fluorine in very low concentration- 1 part per million (ppm) or less is used to reduce the incidence of dental caries. At slightly higher levels (2-4 ppm) it may produce mottling of teeth.
  • In some parts of India and Africa, where fluorine concentration in the drinking water may be above 10 ppm- chronic fluorine intoxication (fluorosis) is endemic and results in skeletal anomalies.
  • Characteristic pathological features are subperiosteal new bone accretion and osteosclerosis (increased bone density), most marked in vertebrae, ribs, pelvis, forearm and leg bones, together with hyperostosis at the bony attachments of ligaments, tendons and fascia.
  • Despite the apparent thickening and density of the skeleton, tensile strength is reduced, and the bones fracture more easily.
  • The first clinical manifestation is usually a stress fracture, back pain, bone pain, joint stiffness and neurological defects (due to hyperostosis encroaching the vertebral canal).
  • Characteristic X-ray features are osteosclerosis, osteophytosis and ossification of ligamentous and fascial attachments. It can be radiologically mistaken for other osteosclerotic conditions such as Paget’s disease, osteopetrosis, renal osteodystrophy, idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis, etc.
  • Note: Fluorine stimulates osteoblastic activity; fluoroapatite crystals are laid down in bone and these are usually resistant to osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention impaired mineralization and secondary hyperparathyroidism.
